Trial_Design.evidence: Patients undergoing right-sided maxillofacial surgery requiring left nasotracheal intubation were randomly allocated

Intervention.evidence: control (tracheal tube in the conventional direction) or reverse (a 180˚ reverse direction, with the tube bevel facing the nasal septum and the leading edge (i.e., the tip) of the bevel pointing away from the nasal septum) groups

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the effect of the reverse bevel and tip direction of the nasotracheal tube on the incidence of epistaxis during nasotracheal intubation via the left nostril.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of epistaxis evaluated using videolaryngoscopy.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of epistaxis in the reverse group was significantly lower than that in the control group (9 [24.3%] vs. 20 [54.1%], P = 0.009; relative risk: 0.45, 95% CI [0.24, 0.85], absolute risk reduction: 29.8%, number needed to treat: 3).

Harms.evidence: Nasotracheal tube-related complications did not occur in either group.
